contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will give the Babylonians control over Egypt just as a person who sells something gives the one who buys it control over that thing. Alternate translation: "I will give control of the land to wicked men" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will sell the land into the hand of wicked men

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "put terror on the land" represents causing the people of the land to be very afraid. Alternate translation: "I will make the people of Egypt very afraid" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will put terror on the land of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "pour out my fury" represents punishing the people because of his great anger. Alternate translation: "For I will act in great anger against Pelusium" or "Because I am so angry, I will punish Pelusium severely" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For I will pour out my fury on Pelusium

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "cut off" represents killing the people. Alternate translation: "kill the very large number of people in Thebes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: cut off the multitude of Thebes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "yoke" here refers to Egypt's power to oppress people. Alternate translation: "when I stop Egypt from oppressing people" or "when I end Egypt's power to cruelly control other nations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: when I break the yoke of Egypt there

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents Egypt no longer being proud of their strength. The reason that they will not be proud is that they will no longer be strong. Alternate translation: "Egypt will no longer be proud about being strong" or "Egypt will no longer have the strength that they were so proud of" (See:[[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: the pride of her strength will be finished

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) the dark cloud represents how sad the people of Egypt will feel. Alternate translation: "It will be as if there is a cloud over Egypt" or 2) there will be a cloud of dust over Egypt from everything that is destroyed. Alternate translation: "A cloud of dust will be over Egypt" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: There will be a cloud covering her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "covered" possibly refers to putting on clothes for mourning. Alternate translation: "I made the water from the springs mourn for the cedar" or "it was as though the springs that watered it mourned for it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I covered the deep waters over it

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's punishment of Pharaoh is spoken of as if the king were the river monster caught in a net. Alternate translation: "So I will gather many peoples and throw my net over you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: So I will spread my net over you in the assembly of many peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: It was common to speak of a person's life as if it were a lamp that could be put out. Alternate translation: "When I destroy you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: when I extinguish you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of making the stars dark as if he were putting a cover over the sky. Alternate translation: "I will make everything in the sky go dark" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will cover the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: The nation of Egypt, symbolized by its king, is spoken of as if it were a building that was collapsing. Alternate translation: "when nations hear about the way I destroyed you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: when I bring about your collapse among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idea of falling down ("downfall") represents dying. Alternate translation: "when I destroy you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: on the day of your downfall

contextId.occurrenceNote: It was normal in biblical language to represent countries and lands as if they were women. Alternate translation: "in it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in her

contextId.occurrenceNote: It was normal in biblical language to represent countries and lands as if they were women. Alternate translation: "over it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: over her

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh continues speaking to Ezekiel. He speaks of the people of Egypt as if they were a woman. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land of Assyria is represented as a woman. Alternate translation: "The people of Assyria and all its army are there in Sheol" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Assyria is there with all her assembly

contextId.occurrenceNote: Shame is spoken of as if it were an object that one could carry where he goes. Alternate translation: "who feel ashamed" or "who are now disgraced" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who carry their own shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: Space being made in Sheol for the dead is spoken of as if the dead were given beds to lie on. Alternate translation: "They gave beds to Elam and all its people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They set a bedroll for Elam and all her multitudes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The warriors' iniquities cover their bodies, although one would expect that their shields would cover them in death. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: their iniquities over their bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: The time during which these warriors were living is spoken of as if it were a place. Alternate translation: "while they were alive" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in the land of the living

contextId.occurrenceNote: Shame is spoken of as if it were an object that one could carry where he goes. See how you translated this in [Ezekiel 32:25](../32/25.md). Alternate translation: "who feel ashamed" or "who are now disgraced" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They carry their own shame

contextId.glQuote: he might turn back from it, and if he does not turn back from his way

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "on us" is a metaphor that means they feel guilty for their transgressions and sins or 2) "on us" is a metaphor that means they realize that Yahweh is punishing them for their transgressions and sins. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Our transgressions and our sins are on us

contextId.occurrenceNote: "we are rotting away because of them." Being destroyed because of sin is spoken of as if the person's flesh were rotting. Alternate translation: "they are destroying us" or "they are killing us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: we are decaying in them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "way" represents how a person behaves. Alternate translation: "if the wicked person stops doing bad things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: if the wicked repents from his way

contextId.occurrenceNote: Acting or behaving in a certain way is spoken of as if it were walking. Alternate translation: "lives according to the laws that give life" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: walks in the statutes that give life

contextId.occurrenceNote: Behaviors or actions is spoken of as if they were a way or road on which a person travels. Alternate translation: "What the Lord does ... the things you do that are not fair" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The way of the Lord ... your ways that are not fair

contextId.occurrenceNote: No longer doing something is spoken of as if it were physically turning away from something. Alternate translation: "stops doing what is right" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: turns away from his righteousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: No longer doing something is spoken of as if it were physically turning away from something. Alternate translation: "stops doing wicked things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: turns away from his wickedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh giving the land to Abraham is spoken of as if Abraham inherited the land. Alternate translation: "Yahweh gave him the land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he inherited the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: In chapter 34, Yahweh speaks of the people of Israel as if they were a flock of sheep and the leaders of Israel were the shepherds that were supposed to care for the flock but have not. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.glQuote: the shepherds of Israel

contextId.glQuote: on the day of clouds and darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh bringing his people back from exile to their land so that he can care for them and keep them safe is spoken of as if he were their shepherd who puts his flock in a place where there is plenty of land, food, and water. contextId.glQuote: I will put them in pastures ... every settlement in the land

contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.glQuote: He will shepherd them

contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.glQuote: when I break the bars of their yoke

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people of Israel as if they were a flock of sheep and Yahweh is their shepherd. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For you are my sheep, the flock of my pasture

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings of this metaphor are 1) "you gave them over to their enemies who killed them with swords" or 2) "you killed them with swords." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you poured them out into the hands of the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "cut off" is a metaphor that means to destroy. contextId.glQuote: when I cut off from it anyone who passes through and returns again

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Mount Seir taking the land of Israel and using it for themselves is spoken of as if they were wild animals that would devour the mountains of Israel. Alternate translation: "they are here for us to devour" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: they have been given over to us to devour

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the land that Yahweh gave to the Israelites as their inheritance. Alternate translation: "As you rejoiced when I made the land of the Israelites desolate" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: As you rejoiced over the inheritance of the people of Israel because of its desolation

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh's fury as if it were a fire. Yahweh loves Israel very much, so he becomes jealous and angry when other nations mock it. Alternate translation: "because of my intense jealousy" or "because of my very strong anger" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in the fire of my fury

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people experiencing shame are spoken of as if they will carry their shame. Alternate translation: "that people will certainly mock the nations that surround you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: that the nations that surround you will certainly carry their own shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people living in the mountains and land of Israel permanently is spoke of as if the people would inherit them. Alternate translation: "They will possess you permanently" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They will possess you, and you will be their inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not enough food growing in Israel so that people die is spoken of as if the mountains of Israel were devouring the people. Alternate translation: "You cause many people to die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You devour men

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not enough food growing in Israel so that people die is spoken of as if the mountains of Israel were consuming the people. Alternate translation: "you will no longer cause the people to die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you will not consume people any longer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh punishing people because he is angry is spoken of as if his fury were a liquid that he poured out. Alternate translation: "I did things to them that showed how angry I was" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I poured out my fury against them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people worshiping idols is spoken of as if the idols made the land physically dirty. Alternate translation: "because they defiled the land with their idols" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for their pollution of it by their idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh forgiving the people and causing them to no longer sin is spoken of as if he would cleanse them with water. contextId.glQuote: I will sprinkle pure water on you so you will be purified from all of your impurities, and I will purify you from all of your idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing the people to no longer be stubborn but to love and serve Yahweh is spoken of as if he will take away their old heart and give them a new heart and spirit. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will give you a new heart and a new spirit in your innermost parts, and I will take away the heart of stone from your flesh. For I will give you a heart of flesh

contextId.glQuote: the heart of stone

contextId.occurrenceNote: People being willing to serve Yahweh is spoken of as if their hearts were soft like flesh. See how you translated this in [Ezekiel 11:19](../11/19.md). Alternate translation: "a heart that is soft like flesh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: a heart of flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person acting or behaving in a certain way is spoken of is if it were a person walking. See how you translated this in [Ezekiel 11:20](../11/20.md). Alternate translation: "enable you to obey my statutes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: enable you to walk in my statutes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Something that is unacceptable to Yahweh is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. Alternate translation: "For I will save you from everything that made me reject you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For I will save you from all of your uncleanness

contextId.glQuote: I will no longer put famine upon you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Experiencing shame is spoken of as if the people had to carry the shame. Alternate translation: "the nations will no longer make you feel ashamed because you suffer from famine" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you will no longer bear the shame of famine among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people of Israel as if they were a flock of sheep. This can be stated in active form. contextId.glQuote: so will the ruined cities be filled with flocks of people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people being destroyed and removed from their land is spoken of as if they had been cut off like a person would cut off a branch or piece of cloth. Alternate translation: "Our nation is destroyed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: We have been cut off

contextId.glQuote: one shepherd over them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of acting or behaving in a certain way as if it were a person walking. Alternate translation: "will live as I have commanded" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: will walk according to my decrees

contextId.occurrenceNote: The intensity of Yahweh's anger is spoken of as if it were as hot as fire. Alternate translation: "because my anger was intense" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
